info.description: Deploys and configures K8s installations able to host VDCs
info.title: Deployment Engine API

post.description:
Creates a Kubernetes installation on each infrastructure and then deploys a VDC on the first one
based on the blueprint passed as parameter.
post.summary: Creates a DITAS deployment with the infrastructures passed as parameter.

parameters.description: The request object is composed of an abstract blueprint and a list of resources to use to deploy VDCs
parameters.name: request

schema.description: CreateDeploymentRequest is a request to create a deployment of a VDC of a given blueprint in a series of resources

blueprint.description: BlueprintType is the serialization of a DITAS concrete blueprint

items.description: AbstractPropertiesMethodType defines a goal tree for a method

dataUtility.description: TreeStructureType is a tree structure with a root and subtrees or leaves

children.description: The subtrees pending from this node

leaves.description: The leaves pending from this node

items.description: LeafType is a leaf in a tree data structure

attributes.description:
The list of attributes defined in the data management section to match. All of them must comply.
requiered: true

description.description: An optional description for the leaf

id.description: Unique identifier for the leaf

weight.description:
The weight in the resolution of the constraint
requiered: true

type.description: The operation to apply to the subtree or leaves

method_id.description: The method identifier this goals apply to

COOKBOOK_APPENDIX.description: CookbookAppendix is the definition of the Cookbook Appendix section in the blueprint

description.description: An optional description for the deployment

infrastructures.description: A list of infrastructures that should be initialized to deploy VDCs of this blueprint

items.description: InfrastructureType represents a cloud or edge site that's able to create resources such as virtual machines or volumes

description.description: Optional description for the infrastructure

name.description: Unique name for the infrastructure

provider.description: CloudProviderInfo contains information about a cloud or edge provider

api_endpoint.description: Endpoint to use for this infrastructure

api_type.description: Type of the infrastructure. i.e AWS, Cloudsigma, GCP or Edge

authentication.description: Authentication information to use on the provider.

items.description: ResourceType represents a resource such as a virtual machine

cores.description: Number of cores. Ignored if type is provided

cpu.description: CPU speed in MHz. Ignored if type is provided

drives.description: List of data drives to attach to this VM

items.description: Drive contains the information of a data drive

name.description: Name of the image to use. Most of the times, it will be available as /dev/disk/by-id/${name} value in the VM

size.description: Size of the disk in MB

type.description: Type of the drive. It can be "SSD" or "HDD"

hostname.description: Assigned hostname after deployment. It's only resolvable from nodes inside the same infrastructure.

ip.description: IP to assign this VM. In case it's not specified, the first available one will be used.

name.description: Suffix for the hostname. The real hostname will be formed of the infrastructure name + resource name

ram.description: RAM quantity in MB. Ignored if type is provided

role.description: Role that this VM plays. In case of a Kubernetes deployment at least one "master" is needed.

type.description: Type of the VM to create

tags.description: List of tags to apply to this infrastructure

name.description: Unique name of the deployment

items.description: DataManagementMethodType contains the data management attributes associated to a method

attributes.description: DataManagementAttributesType contains the data managements values associated to a method

dataUtility.description: The constraints associated to data utility

items.description: ConstraintType is the definition of a QoS constraint

description.description: An optional description for the constraint

id.description: A unique identifier for the constraint

properties.description: The set of properties thresholds associated to this constraints

additionalProperties.description: Either maximum, minimum or value is required.
additionalProperties.title: MetricPropertyType is the definition of a constraint threshold.

maximum.description: The maximum value for the threshold

minimum.description: The minimum value for the threshold

unit.description: The units in which this property is measured

value.description: The value this property must maintain

privacy.description:
The constraints associated to privacy
requiered: false

items.description: ConstraintType is the definition of a QoS constraint

description.description: An optional description for the constraint

id.description: A unique identifier for the constraint

properties.description: The set of properties thresholds associated to this constraints

maximum.description: The maximum value for the threshold

EXPOSED_API.title:
Swagger this is the root document object for the API specification.
It combines what previously was the Resource Listing and API Declaration (version 1.2 and earlier) together into one document.

definitions.title:
Definitions contains the models explicitly defined in this spec
An object to hold data types that can be consumed and produced by operations.
These data types can be primitives, arrays or models.

additionalProperties.description: For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#schemaObject
additionalProperties.title:
Schema the schema object allows the definition of input and output data types.
These types can be objects, but also primitives and arrays.
This object is based on the [JSON Schema Specification Draft 4](http://json-schema.org/)
and uses a predefined subset of it.
On top of this subset, there are extensions provided by this specification to allow for more complete documentation.

additionalItems.description: SchemaOrBool represents a schema or boolean value, is biased towards true for the boolean property

additionalProperties.description: SchemaOrBool represents a schema or boolean value, is biased towards true for the boolean property

definitions.title:
Definitions contains the models explicitly defined in this spec
An object to hold data types that can be consumed and produced by operations.
These data types can be primitives, arrays or models.

additionalProperties.description: SchemaOrStringArray represents a schema or a string array

externalDocs.title:
ExternalDocumentation allows referencing an external resource for
extended documentation.

items.description:
SchemaOrArray represents a value that can either be a Schema
or an array of Schema. Mainly here for serialization purposes

type.description:
StringOrArray represents a value that can either be a string
or an array of strings. Mainly here for serialization purposes

xml.title: XMLObject a metadata object that allows for more fine-tuned XML model definitions.

externalDocs.title:
ExternalDocumentation allows referencing an external resource for
extended documentation.

info.title:
Info object provides metadata about the API.
The metadata can be used by the clients if needed, and can be presented in the Swagger-UI for convenience.

contact.title: ContactInfo contact information for the exposed API.

license.title: License information for the exposed API.

additionalProperties.description:
There are five possible parameter types.
Path - Used together with [Path Templating](#pathTemplating), where the parameter value is actually part of the operation's URL. This does not include the host or base path of the API. For example, in `/items/{itemId}`, the path parameter is `itemId`.
Query - Parameters that are appended to the URL. For example, in `/items?id=###`, the query parameter is `id`.
Header - Custom headers that are expected as part of the request.
Body - The payload that's appended to the HTTP request. Since there can only be one payload, there can only be *one* body parameter. The name of the body parameter has no effect on the parameter itself and is used for documentation purposes only. Since Form parameters are also in the payload, body and form parameters cannot exist together for the same operation.
Form - Used to describe the payload of an HTTP request when either `application/x-www-form-urlencoded` or `multipart/form-data` are used as the content type of the request (in Swagger's definition, the [`consumes`](#operationConsumes) property of an operation). This is the only parameter type that can be used to send files, thus supporting the `file` type. Since form parameters are sent in the payload, they cannot be declared together with a body parameter for the same operation. Form parameters have a different format based on the content-type used (for further details, consult http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/interact/forms.html#h-17.13.4):
`application/x-www-form-urlencoded` - Similar to the format of Query parameters but as a payload. For example, `foo=1&bar=swagger` - both `foo` and `bar` are form parameters. This is normally used for simple parameters that are being transferred.
`multipart/form-data` - each parameter takes a section in the payload with an internal header. For example, for the header `Content-Disposition: form-data; name="submit-name"` the name of the parameter is `submit-name`. This type of form parameters is more commonly used for file transfers.

For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#parameterObject
additionalProperties.title: Parameter a unique parameter is defined by a combination of a [name](#parameterName) and [location](#parameterIn).

Ref.description: Ref represents a json reference that is potentially resolved

paths.title:
Paths holds the relative paths to the individual endpoints.
The path is appended to the [`basePath`](http://goo.gl/8us55a#swaggerBasePath) in order
to construct the full URL.
The Paths may be empty, due to [ACL constraints](http://goo.gl/8us55a#securityFiltering).

additionalProperties.description: For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#responseObject
additionalProperties.title: Response describes a single response from an API Operation.

Ref.description: Ref represents a json reference that is potentially resolved

additionalProperties.description: For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#headerObject
additionalProperties.title: Header describes a header for a response of the API

items.description: For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#items-object
items.title:
Items a limited subset of JSON-Schema's items object.
It is used by parameter definitions that are not located in "body".

Ref.description: Ref represents a json reference that is potentially resolved

securityDefinitions.title:
SecurityDefinitions a declaration of the security schemes available to be used in the specification.
This does not enforce the security schemes on the operations and only serves to provide
the relevant details for each scheme.

additionalProperties.description: For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#securitySchemeObject
additionalProperties.title:
SecurityScheme allows the definition of a security scheme that can be used by the operations.
Supported schemes are basic authentication, an API key (either as a header or as a query parameter)
and OAuth2's common flows (implicit, password, application and access code).

items.description: For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#tagObject
items.title:
Tag allows adding meta data to a single tag that is used by the [Operation Object](http://goo.gl/8us55a#operationObject).
It is not mandatory to have a Tag Object per tag used there.

externalDocs.title:
ExternalDocumentation allows referencing an external resource for
extended documentation.

INTERNAL_STRUCTURE.description: InternalStructureType is the serialization of a DITAS concrete blueprint

DAL_Images.description: Docker images that must be deployed in the DAL indexed by DAL name. It will be used to compose the service name and the DNS entry that other images in the cluster can access to.

additionalProperties.description: ImageSet represents a set of docker images whose key is an identifier and value is a docker image name in the standard format [group]/<image_name>:[release]
ImageInfo is the information about an image that will be deployed by the deployment engine

external_port.description: Port in which this image must be exposed. It must be unique across all images in all the ImageSets defined in this blueprint. Due to limitations in k8s, the port range must be bewteen 30000 and 32767

image.description: Image is the image name in the standard format [group]/<image_name>:[release]

internal_port.description: Port in which the docker image is listening internally. Two images inside the same ImageSet can't have the same internal port.

items.description: DataSourceType is a datasource definition

id.description: The unique identifier of the datasource

parameters.description: A map of parameters relevant for the datasource

Overview.description: OverviewType are general descriptive properties of the blueprint

Name.description: A unique name for the blueprint. It will be identified by this property.

tags.description: A list of tags to apply to this blueprint

items.description: MethodTagType is a structure to define tags per methos

tags.description: The list of tags to apply to the method

VDC_Images.description: ImageSet represents a set of docker images whose key is an identifier and value is a docker image name in the standard format [group]/<image_name>:[release]

additionalProperties.description: ImageInfo is the information about an image that will be deployed by the deployment engine

external_port.description: Port in which this image must be exposed. It must be unique across all images in all the ImageSets defined in this blueprint. Due to limitations in k8s, the port range must be bewteen 30000 and 32767

image.description: Image is the image name in the standard format [group]/<image_name>:[release]

internal_port.description: Port in which the docker image is listening internally. Two images inside the same ImageSet can't have the same internal port.

EXPOSED_API.title:
Swagger this is the root document object for the API specification.
It combines what previously was the Resource Listing and API Declaration (version 1.2 and earlier) together into one document.

definitions.title:
Definitions contains the models explicitly defined in this spec
An object to hold data types that can be consumed and produced by operations.
These data types can be primitives, arrays or models.

additionalProperties.description: For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#schemaObject
additionalProperties.title:
Schema the schema object allows the definition of input and output data types.
These types can be objects, but also primitives and arrays.
This object is based on the [JSON Schema Specification Draft 4](http://json-schema.org/)
and uses a predefined subset of it.
On top of this subset, there are extensions provided by this specification to allow for more complete documentation.

additionalItems.description: SchemaOrBool represents a schema or boolean value, is biased towards true for the boolean property

info.title:
Info object provides metadata about the API.
The metadata can be used by the clients if needed, and can be presented in the Swagger-UI for convenience.

contact.title: ContactInfo contact information for the exposed API.

license.title: License information for the exposed API.

additionalProperties.description:
There are five possible parameter types.
Path - Used together with [Path Templating](#pathTemplating), where the parameter value is actually part of the operation's URL. This does not include the host or base path of the API. For example, in `/items/{itemId}`, the path parameter is `itemId`.
Query - Parameters that are appended to the URL. For example, in `/items?id=###`, the query parameter is `id`.
Header - Custom headers that are expected as part of the request.
Body - The payload that's appended to the HTTP request. Since there can only be one payload, there can only be *one* body parameter. The name of the body parameter has no effect on the parameter itself and is used for documentation purposes only. Since Form parameters are also in the payload, body and form parameters cannot exist together for the same operation.
Form - Used to describe the payload of an HTTP request when either `application/x-www-form-urlencoded` or `multipart/form-data` are used as the content type of the request (in Swagger's definition, the [`consumes`](#operationConsumes) property of an operation). This is the only parameter type that can be used to send files, thus supporting the `file` type. Since form parameters are sent in the payload, they cannot be declared together with a body parameter for the same operation. Form parameters have a different format based on the content-type used (for further details, consult http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/interact/forms.html#h-17.13.4):
`application/x-www-form-urlencoded` - Similar to the format of Query parameters but as a payload. For example, `foo=1&bar=swagger` - both `foo` and `bar` are form parameters. This is normally used for simple parameters that are being transferred.
`multipart/form-data` - each parameter takes a section in the payload with an internal header. For example, for the header `Content-Disposition: form-data; name="submit-name"` the name of the parameter is `submit-name`. This type of form parameters is more commonly used for file transfers.

For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#parameterObject
additionalProperties.title: Parameter a unique parameter is defined by a combination of a [name](#parameterName) and [location](#parameterIn).

Ref.description: Ref represents a json reference that is potentially resolved

paths.title:
Paths holds the relative paths to the individual endpoints.
The path is appended to the [`basePath`](http://goo.gl/8us55a#swaggerBasePath) in order
to construct the full URL.
The Paths may be empty, due to [ACL constraints](http://goo.gl/8us55a#securityFiltering).

additionalProperties.description: For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#responseObject
additionalProperties.title: Response describes a single response from an API Operation.

Ref.description: Ref represents a json reference that is potentially resolved

additionalProperties.description: For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#headerObject
additionalProperties.title: Header describes a header for a response of the API

items.description: For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#items-object
items.title:
Items a limited subset of JSON-Schema's items object.
It is used by parameter definitions that are not located in "body".

Ref.description: Ref represents a json reference that is potentially resolved

securityDefinitions.title:
SecurityDefinitions a declaration of the security schemes available to be used in the specification.
This does not enforce the security schemes on the operations and only serves to provide
the relevant details for each scheme.

additionalProperties.description: For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#securitySchemeObject
additionalProperties.title:
SecurityScheme allows the definition of a security scheme that can be used by the operations.
Supported schemes are basic authentication, an API key (either as a header or as a query parameter)
and OAuth2's common flows (implicit, password, application and access code).

items.description: For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#tagObject
items.title:
Tag allows adding meta data to a single tag that is used by the [Operation Object](http://goo.gl/8us55a#operationObject).
It is not mandatory to have a Tag Object per tag used there.

internal_port.description: Port in which the docker image is listening internally. Two images inside the same ImageSet can't have the same internal port.

Parameter.description:
There are five possible parameter types.
Path - Used together with [Path Templating](#pathTemplating), where the parameter value is actually part of the operation's URL. This does not include the host or base path of the API. For example, in `/items/{itemId}`, the path parameter is `itemId`.
Query - Parameters that are appended to the URL. For example, in `/items?id=###`, the query parameter is `id`.
Header - Custom headers that are expected as part of the request.
Body - The payload that's appended to the HTTP request. Since there can only be one payload, there can only be *one* body parameter. The name of the body parameter has no effect on the parameter itself and is used for documentation purposes only. Since Form parameters are also in the payload, body and form parameters cannot exist together for the same operation.
Form - Used to describe the payload of an HTTP request when either `application/x-www-form-urlencoded` or `multipart/form-data` are used as the content type of the request (in Swagger's definition, the [`consumes`](#operationConsumes) property of an operation). This is the only parameter type that can be used to send files, thus supporting the `file` type. Since form parameters are sent in the payload, they cannot be declared together with a body parameter for the same operation. Form parameters have a different format based on the content-type used (for further details, consult http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/interact/forms.html#h-17.13.4):
`application/x-www-form-urlencoded` - Similar to the format of Query parameters but as a payload. For example, `foo=1&bar=swagger` - both `foo` and `bar` are form parameters. This is normally used for simple parameters that are being transferred.
`multipart/form-data` - each parameter takes a section in the payload with an internal header. For example, for the header `Content-Disposition: form-data; name="submit-name"` the name of the parameter is `submit-name`. This type of form parameters is more commonly used for file transfers.

For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#parameterObject

SecurityDefinitions.title:
SecurityDefinitions a declaration of the security schemes available to be used in the specification.
This does not enforce the security schemes on the operations and only serves to provide
the relevant details for each scheme.

additionalProperties.description: For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#securitySchemeObject
additionalProperties.title:
SecurityScheme allows the definition of a security scheme that can be used by the operations.
Supported schemes are basic authentication, an API key (either as a header or as a query parameter)
and OAuth2's common flows (implicit, password, application and access code).

Swagger.title:
Swagger this is the root document object for the API specification.
It combines what previously was the Resource Listing and API Declaration (version 1.2 and earlier) together into one document.

info.title:
Info object provides metadata about the API.
The metadata can be used by the clients if needed, and can be presented in the Swagger-UI for convenience.

contact.title: ContactInfo contact information for the exposed API.

license.title: License information for the exposed API.

additionalProperties.description:
There are five possible parameter types.
Path - Used together with [Path Templating](#pathTemplating), where the parameter value is actually part of the operation's URL. This does not include the host or base path of the API. For example, in `/items/{itemId}`, the path parameter is `itemId`.
Query - Parameters that are appended to the URL. For example, in `/items?id=###`, the query parameter is `id`.
Header - Custom headers that are expected as part of the request.
Body - The payload that's appended to the HTTP request. Since there can only be one payload, there can only be *one* body parameter. The name of the body parameter has no effect on the parameter itself and is used for documentation purposes only. Since Form parameters are also in the payload, body and form parameters cannot exist together for the same operation.
Form - Used to describe the payload of an HTTP request when either `application/x-www-form-urlencoded` or `multipart/form-data` are used as the content type of the request (in Swagger's definition, the [`consumes`](#operationConsumes) property of an operation). This is the only parameter type that can be used to send files, thus supporting the `file` type. Since form parameters are sent in the payload, they cannot be declared together with a body parameter for the same operation. Form parameters have a different format based on the content-type used (for further details, consult http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/interact/forms.html#h-17.13.4):
`application/x-www-form-urlencoded` - Similar to the format of Query parameters but as a payload. For example, `foo=1&bar=swagger` - both `foo` and `bar` are form parameters. This is normally used for simple parameters that are being transferred.
`multipart/form-data` - each parameter takes a section in the payload with an internal header. For example, for the header `Content-Disposition: form-data; name="submit-name"` the name of the parameter is `submit-name`. This type of form parameters is more commonly used for file transfers.

For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#parameterObject
additionalProperties.title: Parameter a unique parameter is defined by a combination of a [name](#parameterName) and [location](#parameterIn).

Ref.description: Ref represents a json reference that is potentially resolved

paths.title:
Paths holds the relative paths to the individual endpoints.
The path is appended to the [`basePath`](http://goo.gl/8us55a#swaggerBasePath) in order
to construct the full URL.
The Paths may be empty, due to [ACL constraints](http://goo.gl/8us55a#securityFiltering).

additionalProperties.description: For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#responseObject
additionalProperties.title: Response describes a single response from an API Operation.

Ref.description: Ref represents a json reference that is potentially resolved

additionalProperties.description: For more information: http://goo.gl/8us55a#headerObject
additionalProperties.title: Header describes a header for a response of the API

items.title:
Tag allows adding meta data to a single tag that is used by the [Operation Object](http://goo.gl/8us55a#operationObject).
It is not mandatory to have a Tag Object per tag used there.

extended documentation.

TreeStructureType.description: TreeStructureType is a tree structure with a root and subtrees or leaves

children.description: The subtrees pending from this node

leaves.description: The leaves pending from this node

items.description: LeafType is a leaf in a tree data structure

attributes.description:
The list of attributes defined in the data management section to match. All of them must comply.
requiered: true

description.description: An optional description for the leaf

id.description: Unique identifier for the leaf

weight.description:
The weight in the resolution of the constraint
requiered: true

type.description: The operation to apply to the subtree or leaves
